The #2020Census helps determine which areas qualify for the critical resources that children and families depend on for the next 10 years—basically an entire childhood.

May 19 at 11:21 AM ·

Pandemic EBT is a new benefit to help families buy food for their school age children who would normally receive free or reduced-priced meals at schools. Learn more at http://www.dhs.state.il.us/OneNetLibrary/27897/documents/Brochures/4980.pdf

Help us spread the word to Illinois families!

The easiest way to apply is online at https://abe.illinois.gov/abe/access/. Families currently receiving SNAP do not need to apply because these additional P-EBT benefits will be automatically loaded into Illinois LINK EBT accounts.

Families can also print out paper applications in English or Spanish and use mobile devices to scan or photograph their completed applications and email them to DHS.FCS.PEBT@illinois.gov or send them via regular mail to Central Scan Unit, PO Box 19138, Springfield, IL, 62763.

To assist families without internet access, schools can print out and distribute applications, then collect the completed paper applications and submit them (as a group) directly to IDHS for processing.

The easiest way to apply is online at https://abe.illinois.gov/abe/access/. Families currently receiving SNAP do not need to apply because these additional P-EBT benefits will be automatically loaded into Illinois LINK EBT accounts.

Families can also print out paper applications in English or Spanish and use mobile devices to scan or photograph their completed applications and email them to DHS.FCS.PEBT@illinois.gov or send them via regular mail to Central Scan Unit, PO Box 19138, Springfield, IL, 62763.

To assist families without internet access, schools can print out and distribute applications, then collect the completed paper applications and submit them (as a group) directly to IDHS for processing.

All District 186 schools will be closed beginning Monday, March 16, through Monday, March 30, for students.

Staff and teachers will be at school and the buildings will remain open on Monday, March 16, for any students who need to collect belongings. Monday is not a student attendance day.

SCOPE and 21st Century before and after school care programs are also closed beginning Monday.

Spring break will remain as previously scheduled from April 6-13.

This is following the Governor’s directive to the entire state of Illinois to close all schools in light of coronavirus concerns.

We have the responsibility to protect the health and safety of our students and staff and also make every effort to minimize the impact of coronavirus in our community.

We will provide further details through email, social media and our website including how to receive meals during this time if needed. Please check these sources often for updates.

Why does the Census ask the race question? Responses to census questions provide a snapshot of the nation. We ask about a person’s race to create statistics about race and to present other statistics by race groups.In 2010, for example, the statistics illustrated the nation’s changing racial diversity, as well as the size, growth, and geographic distribution of various racial population groups. In addition, the data collected in these questions is needed by federal agencies to monitor compliance with the anti-discrimination provisions of laws such as the Voting Rights Act and the Civil Rights Act.

As a member of the Illinois Municipal Utilities Association (IMUA), CWLP along with other member utilities are offering four - $1,000 scholarships to eligible high school seniors. Eligible students are asked to submit an application and essay (500 words or less) addressing their choice of one of three utility-related questions. Applicants must be high school seniors whose parents or legal guardians are residential customers of CWLP or another IMUA-member utility. The deadline for submissions is Friday, March 6, 2020. A committee of municipal utility officials will select a total of four finalists, each of whom will receive a certificate and a $1,000 scholarship. Winners will be announced in April. Application packets are available online www.imea.org/Documents/IMUAScholarshipApp.pdf.

Superintendent Gill gave a Shout-out to the Ministerial Alliance of Springfield and Vicinity on hosting the annual Dr. Martin Luther King Essay Contest. She expressed how it was an honor to attend and speak at the event where she shared one of her favorite quotes from Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. that he wrote for his school newspaper in 1947 while attending Morehouse College in Georgia.

He was 18 years old when he stated...
“The function of education is to teach one to think intensively and to think critically….” Later in the article he states, “Intelligence plus character – that is the goal of true education.”

The Ministerial Alliance received 99 essays and 97 were from District 186 students. Congratulations and shout-out to the 9 finalists as follows:

Elementary
Harvard Park Elementary School
1. Rontae Cunningham
2. Gage Lyles
3. Samarja Perry

Middle
Franklin Middle School
1. Bella Yu
2. Srihari Gurugubelli
3. Alexandra Orantia

High School
Southeast High School
1. Isaiah Pickett
2. Mariona Summers
3. Springfield High School : Jaelyn Logan
